title: Fine-tuning citrate synthase flux potentiates and refines metabolic innovation in the Lenski evolution experiment
abstract: Evolutionary innovations that enable organisms to colonize new ecological niches are rare compared to gradual evolutionary changes in existing traits. We discovered that key mutations in the <italic>gltA</italic> gene, which encodes citrate synthase (CS), occurred both before and after <italic>Escherichia coli</italic> gained the ability to grow aerobically on citrate (Cit<sup>+</sup> phenotype) during the Lenski long-term evolution experiment. The first <italic>gltA</italic> mutation, which increases CS activity by disrupting NADH-inhibition of this enzyme, is beneficial for growth on the acetate and contributed to preserving the rudimentary Cit<sup>+</sup> trait from extinction when it first evolved. However, after Cit<sup>+</sup> was refined by further mutations, this potentiating <italic>gltA</italic> mutation became deleterious to fitness. A second wave of beneficial <italic>gltA</italic> mutations then evolved that reduced CS activity to below the ancestral level. Thus, dynamic reorganization of central metabolism made colonizing this new nutrient niche contingent on both co-opting and overcoming a history of prior adaptation.
